ArrayLike()

A class used solely to indicate that an object is an "array like" It should never be used directly and is a temporary hack around some poor design decisions.

Source:
  • utils.js, line 384

Bag(serialized)

RID Bag

A bag of Record IDs, can come in two formats:

  • embedded - just a list of record ids.
  • tree based - a remote tree based data structure

for more details on the RID Bag structure, see https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/wiki/RidBag

Parameters:
Name Type Description
serialized String

The base64 encoded RID Bag
Source:
  • bag.js, line 19

deprecate(context, name, message, fn)

Define a deprecated method or property.

A warning message will be displayed the first time the method is called, regardless of the object.

escape(input) → {String}

Escape the given input for use in a query.

NOTE: Because of a fun quirk in OrientDB's parser, this function can only be safely used on SQL segments that are enclosed in DOUBLE QUOTES (") not single quotes (').

Parameters:
Name Type Description
input String

The input to escape.

extend(source) → {function}

Make it easy to extend classes.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
source Object

[description]
Source:
  • utils.js, line 33
Returns:

[description]

Type
function
Example
extend a class

   function Parent () {

   }

   Parent.extend = utils.extend;

   var Child = Parent.extend({
     '@foo': 'bar',
     'greeting': 'hello world'
   });

   Child.foo; // => 'bar'

   var child = new Child();
   child.greeting; // => 'hello world'

jsonify(value, indentlevel) → {String}

Safely encode a value as JSON, allowing circular references. When a record is encountered more than once, subsequent references will embed the record's RID rather than the record itself.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
value Mixed

The value to JSON stringify.
indentlevel Integer

The indentation level, if specified the JSON will be pretty printed.
Source:
  • utils.js, line 268
Returns:

The JSON string.

RecordID(input)

Record ID

Represents a Record ID in a document. Used to differentiate between actual record ids and strings that merely look like them. Without this, it is impossible to differentiate between '#1:12' the string and #1:12 the record id.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
input String | Array | Object

The input to parse.
Source:
  • recordid.js, line 30
Examples
convert a string to a RecordID instance

   var rid = RecordID('#1:1');
   console.log(rid); // => {cluster: 1, position: 1}
   console.log('ID:' + rid); // => "ID:#1:1"
convert an array of strings to an an array of record ids

   var rids = RecordID(['#1:1', '#1:2', '#1:3']);
   console.log(rids); // => [{cluster: 1, position: 1}, {cluster: 1, position: 2, {cluster: 1, position: 3}]
   console.log(rids.join(', ')); // "#1:1, #1:2, #1:3"
check that a RID is valid

   RecordID.isValid('#1:12'); // => true
   RecordID.isValid('not a record id'); // => false
